stem: A client with DKA is being managed with an insulin infusion. Based on the documentation in the DKA-Potassium & Insulin Trajectory Log, why must the nurse add Potassium to the IV fluids even though the client's potassium was 5.8 on admission?

options.text: Insulin causes an intracellular shift of potassium, leading to severe hypokalemia
Potassium is lost primarily through the nasogastric tube
The patient is developing acute kidney failure and cannot retain potassium
Potassium is needed to buffer the rising glucose levels

rationale.correct: This is a **Post-Insulin Potassium Shift (a1)**. In DKA, the serum potassium looks high at first because of the acidosis. However, once IV insulin is started, it acts as a 'key' that opens the cells and pulls potassium **from the blood into the cells**. This causes the blood (serum) level to crash. The **U-waves** on the EKG (1215) are a definitive indicator of hypokalemia. If potassium is not added to the IV bag (once it hits 5.0 or lower), the patient will die of a lethal arrhythmia.
clinicalPearls: DKA Rule: Never wait for K+ to be 'low' to add it to the bag. Start adding it once K+ is < 5.0.
Insulin + Glucose + Bicarbonate all 'sink' potassium into the cells.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking 5.8 (Admission) means the patient has 'too much' potassium.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Differentiate between 'Serum' (what we measure) and 'Total Body' (what is actually inside). DKA patients are almost always 'Total Body Depleted' of potassium due to polyuria, even if the serum looks high.

mnemonic.title: K-In
mnemonic.expansion: Insulin puts the K-IN (In the cell, out of the blood).

exhibits.title: EKG Strip (1215)
exhibits.content: Finding: Presence of **U-waves** directly after the T-wave. Flattened T-waves. Frequent Premature Ventricular Contractions (PVCs).

exhibits.title: Metabolic Log
exhibits.content: Note: Acidosis (High H+) kicks K+ out of the cells into the blood. Once Insulin is given and the pH improves, H+ leaves the cells and K+ rushes **back inside**, leading to a rapid/fatal drop in serum levels.
